subject: Critical Thinking
title: The Illusion of Certainty
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Illusion of Certainty.

hook.text: Weather forecasters who say '70% chance of rain' are more accurate over time than those who say 'it will rain.'.

buildup.text: Humans crave certainty. We'd rather have a wrong answer than no answer. Ambiguity creates psychological discomfort.

discovery.text: Studies show people prefer a definite electric shock to a 50% chance of one.

twist.text: Leaders who express certainty get more followers â€” even when they're wrong. Confidence is mistaken for competence.

climax.text: Embracing uncertainty is a skill. It means saying 'I'm 70% confident' instead of 'I know.' It's harder but more honest.

punchline.text: Certainty feels good. That doesn't make it accurate.

quiz.question: Why do people prefer certainty even when it's false?
options: Uncertainty causes psychological discomfort that feels worse than bad outcomes
